Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 02:13PM susanb2 wrote: Does she like to write? I'm keeping a journel of my breast cancer journey. Also I was pretty forgetful after surgery and a friend gave me  a nice pad to make lists. I'm an avid reader and it was hard for me to concentrate on reading. Another friend brought over several audio books. Good luck to your MIL.
Posts.Title: Gift for recent surgery patient barbmom susanb2

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 10:58PM susanb2 wrote: Hopefully, they will explain all this anyway. It is helpful to know how the lymph system works, where lymph nodes are located so you can divert the flow to other nodes. Have them teach you how to do manual lymphatic drainage yourself. Are you in pain? Are there areas of edema that you can't reach? If so, take someone with you so they can be taught how to do the MLD also. Ask them about exercises for relief and prevention. How many repetitions, how many times a day? I received charts on the lymph system with arrows pointing the direction to rub. Do you need a compression wrap or sleeve? How long to wear it? As far as surgery delays, it probably depends on severity and pain. My PS delayed one fill b/c I was in so much pain. The lymphedema was compressing my intercostal nerve. It took about 1 1/2 weeks to get the swelling and pain under control. She did the next fill even with some swelling and mild pain. Good luck.
Posts.Title: 1st Appointment with Physical Therapist roadqueenie kira

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 07:23AM susanb2 wrote: Sorry you are having to go through this. I had a double mast with TE on 6/2. In regards to the path report, they checked my SNB while I was asleep on the table and called the surgeon that it was negative. So my family knew immediately after surgery. I knew after I finally woke up. In rare cases, I think my surgeon said 2% they find something when the complete path report is done. The doctor had the complete report when I went for my follow-up a week later. I probably could have called the office and got it sooner, but I didn't worry about it since they told me it was negatvie. The way I got through it is prayer. From the time I was diagnosed, I could feel God's presence with me. I am also blessed to have good family and friend support. I talked about it a lot with friends, family and co-workers. I work in an ER so that helped.My co-workers are comfortable with sick people.  I can only imagine how overwhelming it is for someone not comfortable in hospitals and all the medical language. At times I felt my head would explode with all the information. One thing that really helped was having a good friend that checked on me almost daily leading up to the surgery. I could be honest with her about my feelings and she wasn't judgmental and had a way of asking the right questions. Good luck on your journey.
Posts.Title: nervous about my mastectomy... me1ani anne26

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 04:50PM susanb2 wrote: Whenever something stresses me, I read a lot about it. One of my favorites is The 10 Best Questions for Surviving Breast Cancer by Dede Bonner Phd. It has questions about picking doctors, treatment, surgeries, etc. Another good one is Choices in Breast Cancer Treatment by Kenneth Miller MD. It's a little more technical. I picked them both up from the library. You have time to research and make decisions you feel comfortable with. Good Luck.
Posts.Title: Results are cancer..please advise paigelise cookiegal

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 07:37AM susanb2 wrote: I had a sterotactic biopsy in April and it wasn't painful. They used local anesthetic to numb the area. That stung a little. The worse thing about it was lying still on the hard table for over an hour. They had to biopsy 2 different sites. I have 2 little scars and no hematomas or problems afterwards. It was done on Thursday and was called first thing Monday morning with the results,ILC and DCIS. IWhatever decision you make, I wouldn't base it on the pain of the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Sterotactic Biopsy? sjr carolsd

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 06:46AM susanb2 wrote: I got a camisole from Target called Assets for compression. It was only $20. It's made by Sara Bradley? I believe. The same women that came up with Spanx. I got that too thinking it would be better because it was more expensive and at Neimans, but the Target Asset works better. If the drain put out less than 30cc for 2 days, I would be calling my surgeon to get it out before the appointment in 3 weeks. I had my drains in for 3 weeks and I was sick of them. I can't imagine 7 weeks. Good Luck.
Posts.Title: Need help with drain/compression dressing cwrightrn cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 07:27AM susanb2 wrote: When I had the drains, I pinned them to my night shirt to sleep and wore the cami during the day. I can't stand any constriction when I'm sleeping. With my compression cami I still wear it during the day b/c I have a small amont of swelling in my back & under my l arm.  It starts to irritate me late in the evening so I take if off whenever it starts bothering me. My surgery was 7 weeks ago. Don't use heat as it dialates the blood vessels and could cause more swelling. Did you find a cami or anything to help?
Posts.Title: Need help with drain/compression dressing cwrightrn cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 03:34PM susanb2 wrote: It sounds like they don't know what they are seeing. An MRI is much more sensitve in picking up abnormailities. Not an effective screening tool as they are expensive. You lie face down in the scanner and they inject you with IV dye. The scan takes about 40 minutes. It's not painful. Just uncomfortable, especially if you are claustrophobic. It sounds like they are banging the outside of the machine with a hammer.  Why did they wait a month to call if they were concerned? I would be asking the doc for more information. Do they have the MRI scheduled?  Sorry I can't help much with info. The doctor didn't give you much information to go on.
Posts.Title: Please Help southerngal4 tovahsmom

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 10:38AM susanb2 wrote: The nurse navigator told me spray deo was ok to use when having pain under your arm. I checked to make sure it didn't have parabans b/c I read somewhere that was bad. So I used regular old spray Right Guard that was left over in our bathroom cabinet. Are we not suppose to use regular deo b/c of a suppose link to BC? I read that studies haven't shown any linkage. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Is regular deodorant okay to use? roadqueenie lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 11:04PM susanb2 wrote: Hi, Do you already know you have lymph node involvement? Or will they do a sentinal node biopsy? I have had the tissue expanders since 6/2/09. They initially felt like bricks in my chest. They have been a little uncomfortable, bothersome. I can feel them when & bend over. They don't feel natural. Just in the last few days they are softening up a bit. I have been massaging them and exercising and that seems to help. The fill process has been kind of like braces, uncomfortable for a few days but then I'm used to them. Do you have the option of a bilateral mastectomy? If so, it's something to consider. You get better cosmetic results with implant reconstruction and don't have to worry about going through the surgery again. I decided against the tram flap because of the length of time in surgery and the delayed recovery time. Although I considered it, as a tummy tuck would have been nice. The people I know that have had them said there was a lot of pain. Good luck as you travel this journey.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed..decisions to be made ...help brunettesrule jezza

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 04:55PM susanb2 wrote: Hi Anne, I guess thinking we need to be superwoman is part of the personality of people that decide to become nurses. I've always said no sane person would choose to work in an ER where we usually see not only sick people, but people often at the worse time in their lives. With you seeing BC patients it's much the same, the worse time of their lives. It's good that work is allowing you to ease back into it. When you are stronger, you will be able to give the breast patients a unique support and perspective, if you chose to continue in the position. My co-workers have been great, encouraging and supportive. Many of them have told me to take care of myself. The place will still be there when I'm able to come back. Thanks for your encouragment and sharing your story. Susan
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 06:01PM susanb2 wrote:  Nikita, There is so much information to take into account to decide if chemo is worth it. Beast cancer is so complex. There are different types, stages, grades etc. Depending on all this information, you can make an informed decision on, if chemo is worth it for you. Your onc should be able to take the info from your path report and tell you the percentages of reoccurance with and without chemo for your particular situation. If all your lymph nodes were removed, then I would assume they were positve or they wouldn't have taken them out. If my nodes were positive, I would definitely consider chemo.
Posts.Title: after nikita66 Beesie

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 09:54AM susanb2 wrote: Sparrow. So sorry you are having to go through all this. But you can do it. All of us on these boards are doing it and I know you can too. BC can make us a little crazy, especially when we have to cope with the other crap too. I read your vent and you didn't ask for advice, but I'll give you some anyway. I'm very clautrophobic and I had a MRI for my neck several years ago, so when I had to have this one I was more prepared. I recommend Ativan or since you have xanex that should work too. When I walked in the room, I never looked at the machine until after the exam. When I laid down I shut my eyes and never opened them until I was out. I prayed the entire time that God you are enough, I have nothing to fear. If you're not into prayer, perhaps meditation on a positive thought that speaks to you would be helpful. Do you not have other options for a breast surgeon? Mine saw me prior to MRI. She was the one who ordered it. I know it's more trouble but you could tell the imaging center I will be there today to pick up my reports to take them to my PCP. Have them ready. Even though it's more trouble and they should do their job, you may feel better b/c you are taking control. Doctor's offices can be a real pain to deal with. Good luck in getting the ball rolling on your care.
Posts.Title: I just can't deal with this Sparrow one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 05:47PM susanb2 wrote: Hi! It's great to find a group of nurses. I've been an ER nurse for 33 years. I was diagnosed in April and had a bilateral mastectomy with expanders placed on June 2. I'm blessed I didn't have to take chemo or radiation, but have started on Arimidex. I was scheduled to go back to work tomorrow. I was getting anxious about it this weekend. I just didn't know how I could do a 12 hour shift in a busy ER. I get so tired just getting dressed and doing a few things around the house. I'm still in pain due to lymphedema in my back. I guess the Arimidex has a part in the fatigue as well as hot flashes & a few other unpleasant side effects. My PS told me to take 2 more weeks off and use my energy to heal instead of work. I was feeling like a wimp. It helps to know others have had difficulty jumping back in to work also.  For WNYnurse with edema in the chest, I have been going to the Lymphedema Center where they did manual lymphatic drainage several times a week. They have taught me how to do it on myself and gave me exercises. I wear a  Assest camisole from Target and it acts as a compression camisole. It has helped the pain & edema. there was so much swelling it was compressing the intercostal nerve. It was 9/10. Now it's between 3-4.  Hope you are doing better.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 04:03PM susanb2 wrote: Hi Renee, Welcome to the group. This website has been so helpful. I wish I had started getting on the discussion boards when I was first diagnosed back in April. I am sorry you are having to go through this. During the MRI I kept my eyes closed the entire time. I didn't even look at the machine when I walked in. I got through it by praying the whole time that I can do all things through Christ who gives me strength. ED crews are great for support. We may fight like brothers and sisters sometimes, but when the chips are down they are there when you need them. The group I work with has been wonderful and my boss has been very supportive. As you travel the journey that is BC, keep us updated on how you are doing. Susan
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 02:32PM susanb2 wrote: I ended up using a disposable razor with shaving cream very carefully then applying lotion afterwards. The pain could be from nerves that were irritated during the re-excixion and SNB. The pain could also be from lymphedema. Do you have any swelling in your back, chest or arm? You might measure your arms and see if one side is larger. Your dominant hand side may naturally be a little bigger.
Posts.Title: Shaving meganandrileysmom moogie

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 07:11PM susanb2 wrote: Debbie, Sorry to hear about your sister and about your mets also. As nurses we are so used to taking care of everybody else, it is hard to ask for help. Thanks for encouraging us to reach out. I'm sure your sister appreciated you looking to see what she needed. You probably got it right more often than you know. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 02:47PM susanb2 wrote: Hi 2hands4me & JoAnn, I didn't go back Wed.The PS is female & very understanding. She told me to wait and go back July 29. She said we could reevaluate that Mon. if I was still in pain. That will make it 8 weeks off. I hope I do feel like going back so I can save the other 4 weeks of the FMLA. I'm in the process of reconstruction and obviously we never know what will happen in our lives. None of us planned to have BC and I could fall and break an ankle or something and not be able to work. You are right about the skeleton crews, plus it is just busier with sicker patients. I remember several years ago, I could go to work and get through a shift not feeling well. Now it's so crazy, if I'm not on my A game, I'm afraid I could make a mistake and really screw up. Hope it is going well for both of you.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 03:17PM susanb2 wrote: Hi lorijo, It's too bad they want you to commit to a schedule when you are dealing with the chemo. If your place is like my place, they can use help most any day you are available. Can you have your chemo scheduled in advance then work your schedule around that? Maybe you could commit to a day or two, then work in other days when you feel better.   Is there another area at your hospital that may be more understanding of how you feel with the chemo that would be more flexible? Good luck with the schedule.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2009 03:26PM susanb2 wrote: What I did was make a list of what I was looking for in a surgeon. I wanted a female breast surgeon. She of course had to be competent. I wanted someone who would explain things well and not act like they were in a hurry. I wanted to be sure they would take the time to answer my questions. I wanted to feel comfortable with her.  There are too many doctors in my area to settle for someone I didn't like.
Posts.Title: Feel like I am being jerked around... Ang7 SJW1

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2009 10:14AM susanb2 wrote: Ang, I am so sorry you are going through this. You deserve to have all your questions answered and have a caring and competent surgeon. If you live near a city with large medical centers, check with the hospitals and see if they have a nurse navigator for breast cancer patients. They are a valuable resource and will help you through the process. Yes, invasive cancer is more concerning than DCIS and the treatment may vary. With 2 or more cancer sites in a breast it usually takes the lumpectomy option off the table. It would be very disfiguring. I had ILC and DCIS in the right breast and choose a bilateral mast. There are pros and cons to that and something for you to decide with all the information. In retrospect, I'm glad I did as I had two 1mm lesions in the left that didn't show on mammagram or MRI. I would also make an appointment with an oncologist. Often they don't want to see you until they get the final path report after surgery. I insisted and she was able to answer a lot of questions about probable follow-up treatment. Surgeons often don't know all the specifics on the different types of breast cancer and all the treatment options. They are trained to cut. Losing a breast is a big deal b/c it has so much to do with our body image, our sexual identity and it is a body part. Who wants part of your body cut off? It's a real loss, but one you can cope with.  Good Luck on your journey.
Posts.Title: Feel like I am being jerked around... Ang7 SJW1

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 02:32PM susanb2 wrote: Shelly, Sorry you are having to go through all this. The decision making is sometimes the hardest part. I was diagnosed with DCIS and ILC in the right breast. I was told I needed a mx and to consider a double b/c of increase chance of reooccurance in the other breast with ILC. I had a double mx on 6/2/09. I am glad I went with both as the surgical path report showed cancer in the left breast that was too small to show on mammagram or MRI. I struggled with that decision for several weeks, but once I made it I felt better. You are right these decisions are uuugghhhh..... Good luck with whatever you decide.
